commit_message:
Add backward compatibility for old ansible_runner releases

Add backward compatibility for old ansible_runner releases.
Ansible_runner.runner_config under 1.4.x has a different
way to handle envars and doesn't have location isolation behavior.
So we need to handle this two differences in ansible.py code to be
able to use it in stable/train openstack branch.

The lower-constraints of dogpile.cache and keystoneauth1 are bumped
because of requirements bumps in openstacksdk.

The lower-constraint of decorator is bumped because of problem already
fixed by amotoki here: https://review.opendev.org/701706

IIRC dogpile.cache started using decorator's decorate(), but they
forgot to bump their decorator requirement. Later they fixed the missing
requirement, so after dogpile.cache >= 0.8.0 this should not be a
problem anymore:
https://github.com/sqlalchemy/dogpile.cache/commit/13009319c75ba8ff63c508fdd7fe34762af1f123

Change-Id: Ia9b9c216f1d1161ebedac31594a2c464d77f4ae2

commit_message:
Add command: router add/remove route --route

Add commands to osc to call the two new API methods introduced by
new Neutron extension: extraroute-atomic.

Bump our openstacksdk requirement to >=0.38.0 which contains
the corresponding sdk change.

The lower-constraints of dogpile.cache and keystoneauth1 are bumped
because of requirements bumps in openstacksdk.

The lower-constraint of decorator is bumped because of problem already
fixed by amotoki here: https://review.opendev.org/701706

Change-Id: Ia9b9c216f1d1161ebedac31594a2c464d77f4ae2
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/674324
Partial-Bug: #1826396 (rfe)
Related-Change: https://review.opendev.org/655680 (spec)

[{'created': '2020-03-31 14:02:19.000000000', 'message': 'Optimize DVR related port DB query

Save order by in port query when not require fixed_ips,
and save some useless query for dvr subnet mac.

commit_message:
Optimize DVR related port DB query

Save order by in port query when not require fixed_ips,
and save some useless query for dvr subnet mac.

Closes-Bug: #1834308
Change-Id: I6836840edcaa5a21fd2ba9f65ffd24f7e5038fa3
(cherry picked from commit dd96f3775939dc0209396b4bd73038c1962e6a7e)

commit_message:
OSC support to instantiate and show vnf

Added new commands ``openstack vnflcm instantiate`` and
``openstack vnflcm show``.

Blueprint: support-etsi-nfv-specs

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-03-31 19:41:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-03-31 21:04:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I don't think we should implement any sort of locking. We are taking the problem incorrectly here.

The root cause is the following:
2 containers, which have different config volumes, share some bind mounts; so while running at the same step, there is a risk that container-puppet.sh fails for whatever reason related to the config archiving.

See:
https://f2812ca26965a251a9f1-8c8e1caf92c572d2c7c7d35e44c895e7.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/714317/4/check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario000-multinode-oooq-container-updates/3fdf6bf/logs/undercloud/var/lib/tripleo-config/container-puppet-config/step_1/container-puppet-ironic_inspector.json
https://f2812ca26965a251a9f1-8c8e1caf92c572d2c7c7d35e44c895e7.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/714317/4/check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario000-multinode-oooq-container-updates/3fdf6bf/logs/undercloud/var/lib/tripleo-config/container-puppet-config/step_1/container-puppet-ironic.json
https://f2812ca26965a251a9f1-8c8e1caf92c572d2c7c7d35e44c895e7.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/714317/4/check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario000-multinode-oooq-container-updates/3fdf6bf/logs/undercloud/var/lib/tripleo-config/container-puppet-config/step_1/container-puppet-ironic_api.json

3 containers, 3 different config volumes, and all share /var/lib/ironic bind mount.
We need to solve that problem; to make sure they aren't run at the same time. That's it. No complexity with locks, please."}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-03-31 21:28:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I'm proposing this solution: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/716439/"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-01 06:45:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-01 07:03:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I believe we should go the proposed path:

Or maybe create a filter which process the list of container configs, and create the batches in a way where each item is safe to be run with the others in the batch (e.g. if same config_volume, check if image is the same or move it to another batch).'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-01 07:13:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-01 07:14:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Workflow-1

Only wanted to check if the retrying facility actually works.
It may be nice to have retrying capabilities in future, even if dropping the locking part of this change.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-01 07:25:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

we can also take the same approach with retrying but just not using locks at all.

so if something fails because of achieving or whatnot, it will be retried  later and w/o cuncurrency perhaps'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-01 10:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add locks and retrying of puppet config containers

* Before considered failed, allow containers to be retried for a
  limited amount of times and using short delays between retries.
  Currently this is limited to the use with puppet config containers,
  if any has exited with a special status 110. This status means what
  a container could not acquire a lock and must be retried a few more
  times. Also containers will be retried consequently (no async run).

* Add shared volume for locks used in puppet configs.
  In order to discover related config containers, use the common part of
  its config volume prefixes. For example, container-puppet-nova_libvirt
  and container-puppet-nova_api will have their shared locks stored in
  the host's /var/lock/containers/nova dir also
  bind-mounted as /var/lock/container-puppet for any of the other
  container-puppet-nova_* config containers.

Change-Id: I8935f5cd25aea9387fdacf6f68256375a4821ccf
Related-bug: #1868934
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
rabbitmq: Open ports 25673-25683 for CLI tools

Since RabbitMQ 3.7.4, the CLI tools (rabbitmqctl and friends)
parallelize the querying of information from cluster members.  In
order to receive stream data back, the cli instance binds and
registers itself on an available port (default between 35672 and
35682, inclusive).  If these ports are firewalled off, then
rabbitmqctl commands such as list_queues will hang waiting for data
from remote cluster members.

This patch does two things:

1) Reconfigures rabbitmqctl to bind to 25673-25683 instead of the
default range of 35672-35682.  This ensures the ports are not in the
ephemeral port range and avoids unintended collisions.

2) Opens the firewall on 25673-25683 to enable communication.

Resolves: rhbz#1811680

Change-Id: If5caa51cd9a3aef97d06d491dde1d5129cc1a569
(cherry picked from commit a2bc2e10b0de522a81faca62b7b620432b267fbb)

[{'created': '2020-03-12 20:57:55.000000000', 'message': "Authenticate before Authorization

When user is not logged in and given Dashboard has some `permissions`
defined, `require_perms` decorator was raising `NotAuthorized('You are
not authorized to access %s')` instead of `NotAuthenticated('Please log
in to continue.')`.
This was caused by the order of decorating the views. The decorator
which is applied last is called first in the chain as it wraps the
decorators which were applied before.
This means that to check for authentication before checking permissions
we need to apply the `require_auth` decorator after `require_perms`.

Change-Id: I94d3fa5c1472bb72c9111cab14c6e05180f88589

commit_message:
Authenticate before Authorization

When user is not logged in and given Dashboard has some `permissions`
defined, `require_perms` decorator was raising `NotAuthorized('You are
not authorized to access %s')` instead of `NotAuthenticated('Please log
in to continue.')`.
This was caused by the order of decorating the views. The decorator
which is applied last is called first in the chain as it wraps the
decorators which were applied before.
This means that to check for authentication before checking permissions
we need to apply the `require_auth` decorator after `require_perms`.

Closes-Bug: 1869708
Change-Id: I94d3fa5c1472bb72c9111cab14c6e05180f88589

commit_message:
fcos: Upgrade etcd to v3.4.6, use quay.io/coreos/etcd

The tags on quay.io/coreos/etcd follow the same format as
https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/releases compared to k8s.gcr.io which
modifies the canonical version tag by dropping the "v" prefix.

Story: 2007475
Task: 39184

Change-Id: If44eb55a68c13f8e1706242c099578ed1f264d62

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I26f2df6d4657133a5c7e6ed85298aa843c1bdd73
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Update hacking for Python3

The repo is Python 3 now, so update hacking to version 3.0 which
supports Python 3.

Fix problems found.

Update local hacking checks for new flake8.

Remove hacking and friends from lower-constraints, those are not needed
for co-installing.

Change-Id: I926efaef501f190e78da9cab40c1e94203277258

commit_message:
Fix the remaining hacking issues

Fixes W504 and E117, resulting in some indentation changes.

Also fixes code that exceeds the complexity requirement, that is bumped
to 20 (mostly to avoid refactoring the agent heartbeat call, resulting
in conflicts for the deploy steps work).

Change-Id: I8e49f2c039b0ddfca9138f8e148708b7e8b5df7e

[{'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-06 05:34:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-08-06 07:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/674726/1 : FAILURE in 1h 34m 59s'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-08-06 07:53:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-34730 : FAILURE in 2h 12m 44s'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-08-06 12:10:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(21 comments)

this is a hard no on this idea from me.
if we can support the majority of these operation in v1 then i
think that is a blocker for cyborg integration to continue in Train.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-06 13:32:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> this is a hard no on this idea from me.
> if we [can't] support the majority of these operation in v1 then i
> think that is a blocker for cyborg integration to continue in Train.

I don't remember what we discussed at the PTG. Was there general agreement to block these operations? I'm surprised we let the spec fly without being explicit about this, but right now the spec links to [1] to describe support for instance operations, and that doc implies that things like pause and shelve will be supported.

Perhaps this is an interim measure while support for these operations is added incrementally in subsequent patches.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/605237/4/specs/train/approved/instance-ops.rst"}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-06 15:02:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > this is a hard no on this idea from me.
 > > if we [can't] support the majority of these operation in v1 then
 > i
 > > think that is a blocker for cyborg integration to continue in
 > Train.

Did other projects get all their instance op support in a single release? We spent 3 cycles debating the Nova-Cyborg spec, and it was repeatedly stated these things do not happen in a single cycle. If that was true of merging the spec, it is doubly true of implementing all the details.

Secondly, how many operators rely upon shelve, suspend, etc. _with accelerators_ today as critical operations that they cannot do without?

 > I don't remember what we discussed at the PTG. Was there general
 > agreement to block these operations? I'm surprised we let the spec
 > fly without being explicit about this, but right now the spec links
 > to [1] to describe support for instance operations, and that doc
 > implies that things like pause and shelve will be supported.
 >
 > Perhaps this is an interim measure while support for these
 > operations is added incrementally in subsequent patches.
 > 
 > [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/605237/4/specs/train/approved/instance-ops.rst

It was stated in conversations that whatever is not explicitly validated should be blocked, and the blocks can be removed as validation proceeds. The motivation behind this blocking is to ensure that we spend enough time making sure the basics of creating/deleting VMs are rock solid before we go to secondary ops.

It continues to be our intention to support all these ops (except live migration). The question is how much can we get done and by when, given the available contributor time."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-06 16:39:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is a bit heavy handed IMO.

I remember looking over https://review.opendev.org/#/c/605237/ and it seemed like most operations would work, but Sundar is just saying that unless things are tested they'll be blocked until formally supported, correct?

We have a few other cases of things we could think about here and how they were handled, like VGPUs and ports with granular resource requests for QoS bandwidth-aware scheduling.

VGPU caveats are just documented:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/virtual-gpu.html#caveats

That includes things that don't work with instances that have VGPUs attached. Kind of like the feature support matrix [1] but strictly about operations with VGPUs.

For QoS ports, we added a microversion for creating servers with those [2] but blocked move operations since we knew there needed to be work done there. However, we agreed to not require a microversion for the move operation support [3] and just consider it a bug fix. That would be similar behavior / policy to fixing those VGPU operation caveats without a new microversion.

On the other hand we have things like the fact you can't rescue or rebuild a volume-backed server with a new image. There is an approved spec for the latter [4] which includes a new microversion since it's a behavior change. So we just aren't very consistent about when to apply these rules about when a new microversion should be used or how much to explicitly block things (another example of explicitly blocking something recently is NUMA-aware live migration [5]).

I agree with Sundar that I don't think at this pace we can hold off basic server create/destroy support if we hold that up for supporting all other operations. We did that with multiattach volume support and it took 4 releases at least to land that support in nova (we made sure that things like migration worked before we enabled the support in the API).

It seems the options are:

1. Hold up the basic support until you can support other operations (besides live migration) and test them - if even with a dummy cyborg driver, but is that even useful?

2. Gradually phase in the support for the server operations and document the limitations in the meantime but don't actively block them in the API like this change does. They either work (by chance) or they don't, but they aren't officially supported. Once they are supported, we patch them in without a new microversion as bug fixes (or just claim test support so they are no longer considered experimental).

3. Gradually phase in support and actively block what we don't test in tempest (this patch). That seems heavy handed to me as noted. I think docs are probably good enough for now for what is supported, everything else is experimental and if we can tease out what doesn't work through testing then we open bugs for those (like the VGPU case). Another example that just came to mind is UEFI support - we added that in a long time ago [6] and still have quite a few things that don't work with it which are being fixed as bugs.

If you wanted to go with some hybrid of #3 and follow the pattern in [5] you could add a config option to enable the support, or better yet (for the API) a policy rule so that only admins (or no one by default?) could perform other actions on servers with cyborg devices attached so at least the non-admin user gets a 403 (or 409?) back.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/support-matrix.html
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html#maximum-in-stein
[3] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/support-move-ops-with-qos-ports.html#rest-api-impact
[4] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/volume-backed-server-rebuild.html#rest-api-impact
[5] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#workarounds.enable_numa_live_migration
[6] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/mitaka/implemented/boot-from-uefi.html"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-08-06 17:17:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

i prefer option 2 or perhaps the policy rule.

with this patch currently i believe boot,reboot,status and delete would work and everything else would be blocked.

i do not expect interface/volume attach/detach to be affected by
the cyborg integeration so i would expect that to also be supported
similary i think lock/unlock and pause/unpase will just work.
i stongly suspect that online snapshot/backup will work too

if we have to use suspenmd because online snapshot is disabled then
it likely wont work untill suspend is made aware of cyborg devices.

that brings use to the operations that like wont work automatically.

suspend/resume (i suspect we need to extend this to detach and atatach the cyborg devices)
rebuild/evacuate
shelve/unshelve
resize/cold-migate
live-migation

if we did not have support for those operation i could
more or less live with it for the first release.
i have orderd those in the order that i think is simplest to support to hardest.

i think if we can test as many of the operation as we can with the fake driver, document what does not work, documeted what is not tested as experimental and file bugs to fix issue we find, that would be the best way forward.

i just think this current patch is too aggressive in what it blocks.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-08-07 14:35:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Option 2 works for me. Option 1 would mean we won't ever finish the integration.

Also I'm in favor of adding a lot of tests with a fake driver. If we can tease out something with these tests that not just simply doesn't work but also leads to resource leaks or other nasty things then we have to block those operations (like in option 3) until we can implement the real support for them."}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-07 17:48:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So the consensus is Option 2:
> Gradually phase in the support for the server operations and document the limitations in the meantime but don't actively block them in the API like this change does.

We will state the limitations, if any, in Cyborg documentation."}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-07 20:33:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-07 20:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

commit_message:
Block unsupported instance operations with accelerators.

The block is applied to primary operations, such as pause
or shelve, but not to their reverse operations, like
unpause or unshelve, because that is not necessary.

Added functional tests for various instance operations,
including those that work and those that fail.
Rebuild functional test passes.

Change-Id: I016bc1812404ce1019c71b7a3363f34acc3f8aed
Blueprint: nova-cyborg-interaction

commit_message:
Bump hacking to 3.0.0

The new version enables a lot of standard flake8 checks, so a few
fixes are required. W503 is disabled as it conflicts with W504
and the latter seems to be preferred nowadays.

Change-Id: I929ff36eaa47a42bc551f5c37bd40f64bc4f14d0

commit_message:
elasticsearch: Add metadata labels to CronJob

This change adds the same helm-toolkit-generated metadata labels to
the CronJob itself that are applied to the Jobs it creates.

Change-Id: I6a88bae2c4962d37fcc76ace2e32cd41163ffebe

commit_message:
Pass the actual target in os-agents policy

Currently if target is not passed in context.can(),
it use defauls target which is context.user_id, context.project_id.
These defaults target are not useful as it pass the
context's user_id and project_id only which means we tell
oslo policy to verify the context data with context data.

This commit pass the actual target for os-agents policies
which is empty dict because policy rule is system scoped rather
than project, so the token scope check deals with the required
target checking.

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh

Change-Id: I3dc3af38ee40ad49090a64d2f6e9121067c84a05

commit_message:
Bump hacking to 3.0.0

The new version enables a lot of standard flake8 checks, so a few
fixes are required. W503 is disabled as it conflicts with W504
and the latter seems to be preferred nowadays.

Change-Id: I2d3abfd839b32e9ad17970ee586ce581b5ca57ad

commit_message:
Added soft/hard reboot, pause/unpause, lock/unlock tests.

Run as:
    tempest run -r cyborg_tempest_plugin --serial

Works only with '--serial' because each test case uses the
same device profile name but the name must be unique.
This can be easily fixed.

Change-Id: I0a1665a2ccfca133575d6ae0314aac1ca22dfddf

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-31 01:15:48.000000000', 'message': 'Reduce overhead of stack show loop

A stack show of the overcloud is an expensive operation because
resolving outputs results in a nested stack traversal. This change
adds --no-resolve-outputs to the stack show loop which is waiting for
the stack to no longer be IN_PROGRESS.

On my undercloud this reduces stack show time from 14 seconds to 3
seconds. Since polling load is lower now, the polling period is
changed to a shorter 10 seconds.

Change-Id: I34dcf67b36d802f9ccfb65741012e0ed32a15077
'}]
commit_message:
Reduce overhead of stack show loop

A stack show of the overcloud is an expensive operation because
resolving outputs results in a nested stack traversal. This change
adds --no-resolve-outputs to the stack show loop which is waiting for
the stack to no longer be IN_PROGRESS.

On my undercloud this reduces stack show time from 14 seconds to 3
seconds. Since polling load is lower now, the polling period is
changed to a shorter 10 seconds.

Change-Id: I34dcf67b36d802f9ccfb65741012e0ed32a15077

commit_message:
Add support for native TLS encryption on NBD for disk migration

The NBD protocol previously runs in clear text, offering no security
protection for the data transferred, unless it is tunnelled over some
external transport like SSH. Such tunnelling is inefficient and
inconvenient to manage. Support for TLS to the NBD clients & servers
provided by QEMU was added. In tls-everywhere use case we want to
take advantage of this feature to create the certificates and configure
qemu to use nbd tls.

 Conflicts:
       manifests/profile/base/certmonger_user.pp

Resolved conflicts occured because change
I572d53bb6977e16d1deffe0127e17e48a8cda29c which merged after this.

Related-bug: 1793093
Depends-On: Ifa5cf08d5104a62c9c094e3585de33e19e265110
Change-Id: I1db1b60be4907511f0ec0f5aa0f0a45e1c5d9b45
(cherry picked from commit 62861db22df6170123352b978eb9e7f472b67d6f)

[{'created': '2020-03-31 08:52:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for native TLS encryption on NBD for disk migration

The NBD protocol previously runs in clear text, offering no security
protection for the data transferred, unless it is tunnelled over some

inconvenient to manage. Support for TLS to the NBD clients & servers
provided by QEMU was added. This adds support to configure ndb related

commit_message:
Add support for native TLS encryption on NBD for disk migration

The NBD protocol previously runs in clear text, offering no security
protection for the data transferred, unless it is tunnelled over some
external transport like SSH. Such tunnelling is inefficient and
inconvenient to manage. Support for TLS to the NBD clients & servers
provided by QEMU was added. This adds support to configure ndb related
qemu.conf parameters.

Since libvirt >= 4.5 is required ::nova::compute::libvirt::version
checks the OS version to map the libvirt version we can expect and
only configured the nbd parameter then.

 Conflicts:
       manifests/compute/libvirt/qemu.pp
       spec/classes/nova_compute_libvirt_qemu_spec.rb

Resolved conflicts because of missing change
I0d9eb21fcab01266e501b7fc63c5b2bbb244956a

Change-Id: Ifa5cf08d5104a62c9c094e3585de33e19e265110
Related-Bug: 1793093
(cherry picked from commit 80d0c00d54bc1c7cde03d205145c56a2f4e28519)

commit_message:
Handling the OpenStack name in external services

Without this patch, one might wonder which team owns the "OpenStack" name in
an external service.

This should clarify the current ownership for a few known services.

Change-Id: I88996e3302f9bee7c3ab81bd0f5017f300590616

commit_message:
Add openstack-tempest-skiplist under TripleO

openstack-tempest-skiplist is a new project, having the collection
of tempest skiplist which is getting moved out from
openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras repo and can be shared with
TripleO, Openstack Ansible and other openstack projects in
future.

We are keeping it under tripleo group until we find a new group
for the projects shared between TripleO and OpenStack Ansible.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/713809/

Change-Id: Iac55f8933b6dfca07b91bb3c4f01b66bc88ace0d
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

subject: Add pcre to bindep.txt
messages:
[{'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2020-03-25 05:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2020-03-25 08:59:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

This patch seems necessary, since without it e.g. tox-py37 fails if pcre is not installed:

scss/src/scanner.h:17:10: fatal error: pcre.h: No such file or directory [1]

Nevertheless it's a bit strange, that a horizon bindep needs to be added here. But I think it's fair as bindeps aren't handled recursively and for tests we need that in repositories where horizon is included.

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/514dc603d6a74fcea3c4939ecfc01655/log/job-output.txt#1432"}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2020-03-25 09:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2020-03-25 09:17:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2020-03-25 09:26:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Thanks for the update, I think it's good like this."}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2020-03-25 11:44:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-03-26 10:31:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

libpcre is required by pyscss (one of horizon dependencies). pyscss is now working on make the C extension (libpcre-dev optional) again [1]. I believe it will land soon.

I think it is good to have this till then.

Another solution is to release a beta version of networking-bgpvpn which moved horizon to optional requirements, but it is too much.

[1] https://github.com/Kronuz/pyScss/pull/394'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2020-03-26 13:21:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2020-03-26 13:22:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-03-27 07:17:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I believe this is unnecessary now (as pyScss 1.3.7 is in upper-constraints).

Let me use this to check if no bindep change works.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-03-27 07:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-03-27 07:18:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

fake bindep change to trigger the gate.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-01 05:36:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I believe this is no longer needed. All horizon issues around pyscss and setuptools 46 have been solved in the master branch.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2020-04-01 07:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add pcre to bindep.txt

As networking-bagpipe depends on networking-bgpvpn and thus on Horizon
in zuul, pcre is necessary to be installed for successfull gating.

Change-Id: I1851fc2465bd20d73bedd795ca1cf6369af0995f

commit_message:
Update hacking for Python3

The repo is Python 3 now, so update hacking to version 3.0 which
supports Python 3.

Fix problems found.

Update local hacking checks for new flake8.

Remove hacking and friends from lower-constraints, those are not
needed for co-installing.

Change-Id: I59f0854c089a6ed4f0c4dad7755f946dc95ada3a
